subject: Running JUnit on RAD 7 with JNDI referencing on WebSphere 6.1
msgSnippet: 1.    Create an Application Client Project: •    Click File - New - Other - expand J2EE •    Select Application Client Project and click Next •    Click
messageBody:
1. Create an Application Client Project:
 Click File - New - Other - expand J2EE
 Select Application Client Project and click Next
 Click Next (leave the default) until you reach the
Application Client Module
 Uncheck Create a default Main class
 Click Finish
 Don't worry about the error for now, that will be resolved
until you finish the step 3. Please ignore it for now.
2. Configure resources for the application client:
 Open the application client deployment descriptor
(application-client.xml)
 Switch to the References tab
 Add resource references such as data sources, or other server
resources
3. Set the build path:
 Right click the newly created project > Properties > Java
Build Path
 Switch to the Libraries tab and click Add Variable
 Select the JUNIT_HOME variable and click Extend
 Select junit.jar
 Click OK
 The previous error should now be gone
4. Add your JUnit Test Case:
a) Create a new JUnit class
 Create a new JUnit test by going to File > New > Other >
Java > JUnit > JUnit Test Case
 Fill in the necessary fields and select the checkbox to
create the main method as well as the TestRunner statement
 Click Next
 Select methods to test and click Finish
b) Use an existing JUnit class
 Import your existing JUnit class into the appClientModule
directory
 Add a main method with the line
 junit.textui.TestRunner.run(<my_class_name>.class);
5. Update the manifest:
 Double click Deploymen Descriptor to Open
 On Main Class (right pane) click Edit
 On the Main Class text box click Browse and locate your JUnit
class with the main method
 Save and close the editor
6. Create a new runtime configuration:
 Go to: Run > Run
 Select WebSphere v6.1 Application Client (WAS where you want
to test it and where is your JNDI loaded)
 Click New
 Select your EAR file on Enterprise application option
 On Application client module fields select your Application
Client that you recently created from Step 1
 Check enable aplication client to connect to a server
 Select Use Specific Server and choose where you want to run
you JUnit Application Client
 Switch to the Classpath tab
 Click Advanced...
 Select Add Variables and click OK
 Repeat the instructions from step 3 to add junit.jar
 Click Apply to save the changes
 Click Run to launch the application client

Note: If you have problem connecting to your WAS Bootstrap, you may need
to add a program arguments on your Runtime Configuration for Bootstrap.
You can follow the procedure above if you want to bind your Spring JNDI
to WebSphere JNDI DataSource.
